title: 113_hr1322
content: The "Customs Training Enhancement Act" aims to improve the ability of U.S. Customs and Border Protection personnel in classifying and appraising imported articles through educational seminars. The Commissioner will establish educational seminars at U.S. ports of entry to help Customs and Border Protection personnel classify and appraise imported articles, including identifying mislabeling and transshipment. At least 15 seminars will be held each year, with the option to hold fewer if deemed appropriate. The Commissioner will establish educational seminars at U.S. ports of entry to help Customs and Border Protection personnel classify and appraise imported articles, including identifying mislabeling and transshipment. The seminars will provide instruction on conducting physical inspections and reviewing documentation to determine the country of origin of imported articles. The Commissioner will establish educational seminars at U.S. ports of entry to ensure the accuracy of the country of origin and industry supply chain information listed in the manifest or accompanying documentation. The approval of instructional materials will be subject to the Commissioner's approval. The Commissioner will cover the costs and expenses for conducting the seminars and providing resources for Customs and Border Protection personnel, Immigration and Customs Enforcement personnel, and interested parties. The Commissioner will establish educational seminars at U.S. ports of entry to ensure the accuracy of country of origin information. Customs Enforcement personnel, Immigration and Customs Enforcement personnel, and interested parties will provide instruction and training. The selection process will evaluate interested parties based on availability, mislabeling incidence, and other criteria. The Commissioner will publish a detailed description of the process and criteria for evaluating interested parties for educational seminars on country of origin information accuracy at U.S. ports of entry. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, the term "Commissioner" refers to the Commissioner responsible for U.S. Customs and Border Protection. The term "comparable domestic product" means a product similar to an imported article covered by an educational seminar. "Customs laws of the United States" refer to laws enforced by U.S. Customs and Border Protection. An "interested party" includes a manufacturer, producer, or wholesaler of a comparable domestic product in the U.S. The term "United States" refers to the customs territory of the United States. An interested party includes a certified union, recognized union, group of workers, trade or business association, or association with members engaged in manufacturing, producing, or wholesaling a comparable domestic product in the United States. The term "U.S. Customs and Border Protection personnel" refers to Import Specialists and other appropriate employees of U.S. Customs and Border Protection. Authorization of appropriations for $3,000,000 annually from 2013 to 2017 is granted to carry out this Act.
